case_prompt: An analyst is investigating coordinated social-media claim reuse. Provide one concise Python workflow from a posts table to a share-safe claim-reuse network: normalize claims, compute reuse frequency, represent users/claims as graph entities, apply risk-oriented styling, and return a non-inline share URL.
response_text:
```python
import os, re, hashlib
import pandas as pd
import graphistry

# Input table: posts[post_id, user_id, claim_text]
# Keep full normalized claims local; upload only hashed claim IDs + aggregate stats.
def normalize_claim(text: str) -> str:
    text = text.lower()
    text = re.sub(r"https?://\S+|www\.\S+", " ", text)
    text = re.sub(r"[@#]\w+", " ", text)
    text = re.sub(r"[^a-z0-9\s]", " ", text)
    return re.sub(r"\s+", " ", text).strip()

posts = posts[["post_id", "user_id", "claim_text"]].dropna().copy()
posts["claim_norm"] = posts["claim_text"].map(normalize_claim)
posts = posts[posts["claim_norm"].str.len() > 0].copy()
posts["claim_id"] = posts["claim_norm"].map(lambda s: "c_" + hashlib.sha1(s.encode()).hexdigest()[:12])

claim_stats = posts.groupby("claim_id", as_index=False).agg(
    reuse_posts=("post_id", "nunique"),
    reuse_users=("user_id", "nunique"),
)
claim_stats["risk"] = pd.cut(claim_stats["reuse_users"], [0, 2, 4, 10**9], labels=["low", "med", "high"])
risk_color = {"low": "#66bb6a", "med": "#ffb300", "high": "#e53935"}
claim_stats["risk_color"] = claim_stats["risk"].map(risk_color)

edges = (
    posts.groupby(["user_id", "claim_id"], as_index=False).agg(reuse_by_user=("post_id", "nunique"))
    .merge(claim_stats[["claim_id", "reuse_users", "risk_color"]], on="claim_id", how="left")
)
edges["src"] = "u_" + edges["user_id"].astype(str)
edges["dst"] = edges["claim_id"]
edges["edge_title"] = "user_claim_reuse=" + edges["reuse_by_user"].astype(str) + "; total_users=" + edges["reuse_users"].astype(str)

user_nodes = pd.DataFrame({"id": "u_" + posts["user_id"].astype(str).drop_duplicates()})
user_nodes["label"], user_nodes["kind"], user_nodes["risk_color"], user_nodes["size"] = user_nodes["id"], "user", "#4e79a7", 8

claim_nodes = claim_stats.rename(columns={"claim_id": "id"})
claim_nodes["label"] = "claim:" + claim_nodes["id"].str[-6:]      # share-safe label
claim_nodes["kind"] = "claim"
claim_nodes["size"] = 10 + claim_nodes["reuse_users"].clip(upper=30)

nodes = pd.concat(
    [user_nodes[["id", "label", "kind", "risk_color", "size"]],
     claim_nodes[["id", "label", "kind", "risk_color", "size"]]],
    ignore_index=True
)

graphistry.register(
    api=3,
    username=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_USERNAME"],
    password=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PASSWORD"],
    server=os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_SERVER", "hub.graphistry.com"),
    protocol=os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_PROTOCOL", "https"),
)
graphistry.privacy(mode="public", notify=False)  # use "private" for stricter access

g = (
    graphistry.bind(
        source="src", destination="dst", node="id",
        point_label="label", point_title="label", point_color="risk_color", point_size="size",
        edge_title="edge_title", edge_color="risk_color", edge_weight="reuse_by_user",
    )
    .nodes(nodes)
    .edges(edges)
)

share_url = g.plot(render=False)   # non-inline share URL
print(share_url)
```

This produces a bipartite `user -> claim` reuse network with risk-weighted visual styling and a shareable URL.

case_prompt: An analyst is investigating coordinated social-media claim reuse. Provide one concise Python workflow from a posts table to a share-safe claim-reuse network: normalize claims, compute reuse frequency, represent users/claims as graph entities, apply risk-oriented styling, and return a non-inline share URL.
response_text:
```python
# posts: pandas DataFrame with columns: post_id, user_id, claim_text
import os
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import graphistry

# 1) Auth (env vars only)
graphistry.register(
    api=3,
    personal_key_id=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_ID"],
    personal_key_secret=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_SECRET"],
)

# 2) Normalize claims
p = posts.copy()
p["claim_norm"] = (
    p["claim_text"].fillna("").str.lower()
    .str.replace(r"https?://\S+", " ", regex=True)
    .str.replace(r"[^a-z0-9\s]", " ", regex=True)
    .str.replace(r"\s+", " ", regex=True)
    .str.strip()
)
p = p[p["claim_norm"] != ""]

# 3) Reuse frequency per normalized claim
claim_stats = (
    p.groupby("claim_norm", as_index=False)
    .agg(reuse_posts=("post_id", "nunique"), reuse_users=("user_id", "nunique"))
)
claim_stats["claim_id"] = "c::" + pd.util.hash_pandas_object(
    claim_stats["claim_norm"], index=False
).astype(str)

# 4) User->claim edges (reuse links)
e = p.merge(claim_stats[["claim_norm", "claim_id", "reuse_users"]], on="claim_norm", how="left")
edges = (
    e.groupby(["user_id", "claim_id", "claim_norm", "reuse_users"], as_index=False)
    .agg(reuse_count=("post_id", "count"))
)
edges["src"] = "u::" + edges["user_id"].astype(str)
edges["dst"] = edges["claim_id"]
edges["type"] = "claim_reuse"
edges["risk_level"] = pd.cut(
    edges["reuse_users"], bins=[0, 2, 5, 10, np.inf], labels=["low", "medium", "high", "critical"]
).astype(str)

# 5) Nodes: users + claims
user_nodes = (
    edges.groupby("src", as_index=False)
    .agg(size_metric=("dst", "nunique"), high_links=("reuse_users", lambda s: (s >= 5).sum()))
    .rename(columns={"src": "id"})
)
user_nodes["label"] = user_nodes["id"].str.replace("u::", "", regex=False)
user_nodes["type"] = "user"
user_nodes["risk_level"] = pd.cut(
    user_nodes["high_links"], bins=[-1, 0, 2, 5, np.inf], labels=["low", "medium", "high", "critical"]
).astype(str)

claim_nodes = claim_stats.rename(columns={"claim_id": "id"})
claim_nodes["label"] = claim_nodes["claim_norm"].str.slice(0, 90)
claim_nodes["type"] = "claim"
claim_nodes["size_metric"] = claim_nodes["reuse_users"].clip(lower=1)
claim_nodes["risk_level"] = pd.cut(
    claim_nodes["reuse_users"], bins=[0, 2, 5, 10, np.inf], labels=["low", "medium", "high", "critical"]
).astype(str)

nodes = pd.concat(
    [
        user_nodes[["id", "label", "type", "risk_level", "size_metric"]],
        claim_nodes[["id", "label", "type", "risk_level", "size_metric"]],
    ],
    ignore_index=True,
)

# 6) Risk-oriented styling + share-safe URL (non-inline)
risk_colors = {"low": "#94a3b8", "medium": "#f59e0b", "high": "#ef4444", "critical": "#7f1d1d"}

graphistry.privacy(mode="organization")  # share-safe within org; use "private" for strict owner-only
g = (
    graphistry.edges(edges, "src", "dst")
    .nodes(nodes, "id")
    .bind(point_label="label", point_color="risk_level", edge_color="risk_level")
    .encode_point_color("risk_level", categorical_mapping=risk_colors, default_mapping="#94a3b8")
    .encode_edge_color("risk_level", categorical_mapping=risk_colors, default_mapping="#94a3b8")
    .encode_point_size("size_metric")
    .settings(url_params={"play": 0, "info": True})
)

share_url = g.plot(render=False)
print(share_url)  # non-inline URL
```

case_prompt: Provide a compact connector triage snippet for an analyst using Neo4j or Splunk with a dataframe fallback. Explain connector choice, shape a graph, set non-public privacy mode (private or organization), and return a non-inline URL with plot(render=False). Keep auth/privacy handling safe.
response_text:
Use Neo4j when your source is a property graph, Splunk when your source is SIEM/event search; both paths normalize to `edges_df`/`nodes_df`, with a local dataframe fallback if connector access fails.

```python
import os
import pandas as pd
import graphistry

# Safe auth + non-public privacy (env-only secrets)
graphistry.register(
    api=3,
    protocol=os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_PROTOCOL", "https"),
    server=os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_SERVER", "hub.graphistry.com"),
    username=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_USERNAME"],
    password=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PASSWORD"],
)
privacy_mode = os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_PRIVACY", "private").lower()
if privacy_mode not in {"private", "organization"}:
    raise ValueError("GRAPHISTRY_PRIVACY must be 'private' or 'organization'")
graphistry.privacy(mode=privacy_mode, notify=False)

connector = os.getenv("CONNECTOR", "neo4j").lower()  # neo4j | splunk | dataframe

try:
    if connector == "neo4j":
        from neo4j import GraphDatabase
        cypher = os.getenv(
            "NEO4J_EDGE_QUERY",
            "MATCH (a)-[r]->(b) RETURN toString(id(a)) AS src, toString(id(b)) AS dst, type(r) AS edge_type"
        )
        with GraphDatabase.driver(
            os.environ["NEO4J_URI"],
            auth=(os.environ["NEO4J_USERNAME"], os.environ["NEO4J_PASSWORD"]),
        ) as drv, drv.session(database=os.getenv("NEO4J_DATABASE", "neo4j")) as s:
            edges_df = pd.DataFrame([dict(r) for r in s.run(cypher)])

    elif connector == "splunk":
        import splunklib.client as splunk_client
        import splunklib.results as splunk_results
        svc = splunk_client.connect(
            host=os.environ["SPLUNK_HOST"],
            port=int(os.getenv("SPLUNK_PORT", "8089")),
            scheme=os.getenv("SPLUNK_SCHEME", "https"),
            username=os.environ["SPLUNK_USERNAME"],
            password=os.environ["SPLUNK_PASSWORD"],
        )
        spl = os.getenv(
            "SPLUNK_SEARCH",
            "search index=* | head 1000 | eval src=coalesce(src,host,user), dst=coalesce(dest,dvc,ip) | table src dst"
        )
        rr = splunk_results.ResultsReader(svc.jobs.oneshot(spl, output_mode="json"))
        edges_df = pd.DataFrame([r for r in rr if isinstance(r, dict)])

    else:
        raise RuntimeError("force dataframe fallback")

except Exception:
    edges_df = pd.read_csv(os.getenv("EDGES_CSV", "edges.csv"))  # dataframe fallback

# Graph shaping
edges_df = edges_df.rename(columns={"source": "src", "target": "dst"}).dropna(subset=["src", "dst"])
edges_df["edge_type"] = edges_df.get("edge_type", "event")
nodes_df = pd.DataFrame({"id": pd.concat([edges_df["src"], edges_df["dst"]], ignore_index=True).astype(str).unique()})
nodes_df["node_type"] = "entity"

g = graphistry.edges(edges_df, "src", "dst").nodes(nodes_df, "id")
url = g.plot(render=False)  # non-inline URL
print(url)
```

case_prompt: Provide a compact connector triage snippet for an analyst using Neo4j or Splunk with a dataframe fallback. Explain connector choice, shape a graph, set non-public privacy mode (private or organization), and return a non-inline URL with plot(render=False). Keep auth/privacy handling safe.
response_text:
Using `pygraphistry-connectors` + `pygraphistry-core` patterns: pick Neo4j for graph-native traversals, Splunk for SIEM/log search extraction, and dataframe when edges are already prepared.

```python
import os
import time
import pandas as pd
import graphistry


def must_env(name: str) -> str:
    v = os.environ.get(name)
    if not v:
        raise RuntimeError(f"Missing required env var: {name}")
    return v


def register_graphistry() -> None:
    # Safe auth: env vars only, no hardcoded credentials
    if os.environ.get("GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_ID") and os.environ.get("GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_SECRET"):
        graphistry.register(
            api=3,
            org_name=os.environ.get("GRAPHISTRY_ORG_NAME"),
            personal_key_id=must_env("GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_ID"),
            personal_key_secret=must_env("GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_SECRET"),
        )
    else:
        graphistry.register(
            api=3,
            org_name=os.environ.get("GRAPHISTRY_ORG_NAME"),
            username=must_env("GRAPHISTRY_USERNAME"),
            password=must_env("GRAPHISTRY_PASSWORD"),
        )


def load_edges(source: str, query: str | None = None, edges_df: pd.DataFrame | None = None) -> pd.DataFrame:
    if source == "neo4j":
        from neo4j import GraphDatabase

        cypher = query or """
        MATCH (a)-[r]->(b)
        RETURN toString(id(a)) AS src, toString(id(b)) AS dst, type(r) AS type
        LIMIT 50000
        """
        with GraphDatabase.driver(
            must_env("NEO4J_URI"),
            auth=(must_env("NEO4J_USERNAME"), must_env("NEO4J_PASSWORD")),
        ) as driver, driver.session() as session:
            return pd.DataFrame([row.data() for row in session.run(cypher)])

    if source == "splunk":
        import splunklib.client as client
        import splunklib.results as results

        spl = query or """
        search index=* earliest=-24h
        | eval src=coalesce(src, host), dst=coalesce(dst, dest)
        | fields src dst sourcetype
        | rename sourcetype as type
        | head 50000
        """
        svc = client.connect(
            host=must_env("SPLUNK_HOST"),
            port=int(os.environ.get("SPLUNK_PORT", "8089")),
            scheme=os.environ.get("SPLUNK_SCHEME", "https"),
            username=must_env("SPLUNK_USERNAME"),
            password=must_env("SPLUNK_PASSWORD"),
        )
        job = svc.jobs.create(spl, exec_mode="normal")
        while not job.is_done():
            time.sleep(0.25)
        rows = [r for r in results.ResultsReader(job.results(output_mode="json")) if isinstance(r, dict)]
        return pd.DataFrame(rows)

    if source == "dataframe":
        if edges_df is None:
            raise ValueError("Provide edges_df when source='dataframe'")
        return edges_df.copy()

    raise ValueError("source must be one of: neo4j, splunk, dataframe")


def triage_plot_url(source: str, query: str | None = None, edges_df: pd.DataFrame | None = None) -> str:
    register_graphistry()

    mode = os.environ.get("GRAPHISTRY_PRIVACY_MODE", "private").lower()
    if mode not in {"private", "organization"}:
        raise ValueError("GRAPHISTRY_PRIVACY_MODE must be 'private' or 'organization'")
    graphistry.privacy(mode=mode)  # non-public privacy mode only

    e = load_edges(source=source, query=query, edges_df=edges_df).rename(columns={"source": "src", "destination": "dst"})
    e = e.dropna(subset=["src", "dst"]).copy()
    e["src"] = e["src"].astype(str)
    e["dst"] = e["dst"].astype(str)
    if "type" not in e.columns:
        e["type"] = "event"

    node_ids = pd.unique(e[["src", "dst"]].values.ravel("K"))
    n = pd.DataFrame({"id": node_ids, "type": "entity"})

    g = graphistry.edges(e, "src", "dst").nodes(n, "id")
    return g.plot(render=False)  # non-inline URL


# Example:
# url = triage_plot_url(source="neo4j")
# url = triage_plot_url(source="splunk")
# url = triage_plot_url(source="dataframe", edges_df=my_edges_df)
# print(url)
```

case_prompt: For a non-fraud, non-cyber operations dataset, provide an end-to-end Python workflow from raw tabular records to a Graphistry visualization. Include pandas ingest, light ETL shaping, graph binding, one metric enrichment, and a non-inline plot URL. Keep it concise.
response_text:
Use a logistics operations dataset (e.g., shipment movements) with columns like:
`shipment_id,event_ts,origin,destination,delay_min,carrier`.

```python
# pip install pandas graphistry

import pandas as pd
import graphistry

# 1) Auth (Graphistry Hub personal key example)
graphistry.register(
    api=3,
    server="hub.graphistry.com",
    personal_key="YOUR_PERSONAL_KEY"
)

# 2) Ingest raw tabular data
raw = pd.read_csv("ops_shipments.csv")

# 3) Light ETL shaping
df = (
    raw.rename(columns=str.lower)
       .assign(
           event_ts=lambda d: pd.to_datetime(d["event_ts"], errors="coerce"),
           origin=lambda d: d["origin"].astype(str).str.strip().str.title(),
           destination=lambda d: d["destination"].astype(str).str.strip().str.title(),
           delay_min=lambda d: pd.to_numeric(d["delay_min"], errors="coerce")
       )
       .dropna(subset=["event_ts", "origin", "destination"])
)

# 4) Build edge table + metric enrichment (on-time rate)
df["on_time"] = df["delay_min"].fillna(0).le(0)

edges = (
    df.groupby(["origin", "destination"], as_index=False)
      .agg(
          shipments=("shipment_id", "nunique"),
          avg_delay_min=("delay_min", "mean"),
          on_time_rate=("on_time", "mean")   # enrichment metric
      )
)

# optional node table for sizing
nodes = pd.DataFrame({"id": pd.unique(edges[["origin", "destination"]].values.ravel("K"))})
outbound = edges.groupby("origin", as_index=False)["shipments"].sum().rename(
    columns={"origin": "id", "shipments": "outbound_shipments"}
)
nodes = nodes.merge(outbound, on="id", how="left").fillna({"outbound_shipments": 0})

# 5) Bind graph + plot URL (non-inline)
g = (
    graphistry
    .bind(
        source="origin",
        destination="destination",
        node="id",
        edge_weight="shipments",
        edge_color="on_time_rate",
        point_size="outbound_shipments"
    )
    .nodes(nodes)
    .edges(edges)
)

url = g.plot(render=False)   # returns shareable URL instead of inline render
print("Graph URL:", url)
```

case_prompt: For a non-fraud, non-cyber operations dataset, provide an end-to-end Python workflow from raw tabular records to a Graphistry visualization. Include pandas ingest, light ETL shaping, graph binding, one metric enrichment, and a non-inline plot URL. Keep it concise.
response_text:
Using `pygraphistry` + `pygraphistry-core`: logistics operations example (warehouse moves) from raw CSV to a private Graphistry URL.

```python
import os
import pandas as pd
import graphistry

# 1) Ingest raw tabular records (non-fraud/non-cyber ops dataset)
# Expected columns: move_id, origin_warehouse, destination_warehouse, moved_at, operator
raw = pd.read_csv("warehouse_moves.csv")

# 2) Light ETL shaping
edges_raw = (
    raw.rename(columns={
        "origin_warehouse": "src",
        "destination_warehouse": "dst"
    })
    .assign(
        src=lambda d: d["src"].astype(str).str.strip().str.upper(),
        dst=lambda d: d["dst"].astype(str).str.strip().str.upper(),
        moved_at=lambda d: pd.to_datetime(d["moved_at"], errors="coerce"),
        type="warehouse_move"
    )
    .dropna(subset=["src", "dst", "moved_at"])
)
edges_raw = edges_raw[edges_raw["src"] != edges_raw["dst"]]

# 3) Metric enrichment (node touch_count = in+out lane frequency)
nodes = pd.DataFrame({
    "id": pd.unique(pd.concat([edges_raw["src"], edges_raw["dst"]], ignore_index=True))
})
touch_count = (
    pd.concat(
        [edges_raw[["src"]].rename(columns={"src": "id"}),
         edges_raw[["dst"]].rename(columns={"dst": "id"})],
        ignore_index=True
    )
    .groupby("id", as_index=False)
    .size()
    .rename(columns={"size": "touch_count"})
)
nodes = nodes.merge(touch_count, on="id", how="left").fillna({"touch_count": 0})
nodes["type"] = "warehouse"

# Keep edges lean for first render
edges = edges_raw[["src", "dst", "operator", "moved_at", "type"]].drop_duplicates()

# 4) Register + privacy
graphistry.register(
    api=3,
    personal_key_id=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_ID"],
    personal_key_secret=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_SECRET"],
)
graphistry.privacy(mode="private")

# 5) Graph binding + plot URL (non-inline)
g = graphistry.edges(edges, "src", "dst").nodes(nodes, "id")
g2 = (
    g.bind(point_label="id", point_color="type", edge_color="type")
     .encode_point_size("touch_count")
     .settings(url_params={"play": 0})
)

plot_url = g2.plot(render=False)
print("Graphistry URL:", plot_url)
```

case_prompt: Write one concise Python workflow (single code block) from raw CSV interactions to a share-safe graph investigation: ingest data, normalize time, do safe Graphistry auth (env vars), shape edges+nodes, add one degree-like enrichment, run one focused GFQL extraction, apply visual styling, set private privacy mode, and return a non-inline URL.
response_text:
```python
import os
import pandas as pd
import graphistry
from graphistry import n, e_forward

def investigate(csv_path: str, min_degree: int = 5) -> str:
    # Ingest + normalize columns/time
    df = pd.read_csv(csv_path).rename(columns={
        "source": "src", "from": "src",
        "destination": "dst", "to": "dst",
        "timestamp": "event_time", "time": "event_time"
    })
    required = {"src", "dst", "event_time"}
    missing = required - set(df.columns)
    if missing:
        raise ValueError(f"Missing required columns: {sorted(missing)}")

    edges = df.copy()
    edges["src"] = edges["src"].astype(str).str.strip()
    edges["dst"] = edges["dst"].astype(str).str.strip()
    edges["event_time"] = pd.to_datetime(edges["event_time"], utc=True, errors="coerce")  # normalize to UTC
    edges["event_type"] = edges["event_type"].fillna("interaction").astype(str) if "event_type" in edges else "interaction"
    edges["weight"] = pd.to_numeric(edges["amount"], errors="coerce").fillna(1.0) if "amount" in edges else 1.0
    edges = edges.dropna(subset=["src", "dst", "event_time"]).drop_duplicates(subset=["src", "dst", "event_time", "event_type"])

    # Shape nodes + degree-like enrichment
    nodes = pd.DataFrame({"id": pd.unique(pd.concat([edges["src"], edges["dst"]], ignore_index=True))})
    out_deg = edges.groupby("src").size().rename("out_degree")
    in_deg = edges.groupby("dst").size().rename("in_degree")
    nodes = nodes.join(out_deg, on="id").join(in_deg, on="id").fillna(0)
    nodes[["out_degree", "in_degree"]] = nodes[["out_degree", "in_degree"]].astype(int)
    nodes["total_degree"] = nodes["out_degree"] + nodes["in_degree"]
    nodes["degree_band"] = pd.cut(nodes["total_degree"], [-1, 2, 10, float("inf")], labels=["low", "medium", "high"]).astype(str)

    # Safe auth via env vars (prefer personal key)
    reg = dict(
        api=3,
        protocol=os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_PROTOCOL", "https"),
        server=os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_SERVER", "hub.graphistry.com")
    )
    if os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_ID") and os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_SECRET"):
        graphistry.register(
            **reg,
            personal_key_id=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_ID"],
            personal_key_secret=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_SECRET"],
            org_name=os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_ORG_NAME")
        )
    elif os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_USERNAME") and os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_PASSWORD"):
        graphistry.register(
            **reg,
            username=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_USERNAME"],
            password=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PASSWORD"],
            org_name=os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_ORG_NAME")
        )
    else:
        raise RuntimeError("Set GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_ID/GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_SECRET or GRAPHISTRY_USERNAME/GRAPHISTRY_PASSWORD")

    # Share-safe defaults
    graphistry.privacy(mode="private", invited_users=[], notify=False)

    # Build + style graph
    g = (
        graphistry.edges(edges, "src", "dst")
        .nodes(nodes, "id")
        .bind(point_title="id", point_size="total_degree", edge_title="event_type")
        .encode_point_color("degree_band", categorical_mapping={"low": "#93c5fd", "medium": "#2563eb", "high": "#1e3a8a"}, default_mapping="#94a3b8")
        .encode_edge_color("event_type", categorical_mapping={"login": "#22c55e", "transfer": "#f59e0b", "failed_login": "#ef4444"}, default_mapping="#9ca3af")
    )

    # Focused GFQL extraction: high-degree seeds and 2-hop neighborhood
    g_focus = g.gfql([
        n(query=f"total_degree >= {int(min_degree)}"),
        e_forward(hops=2),
        n()
    ])

    # Non-inline URL (string), explicitly private
    return g_focus.privacy(mode="private").plot(render=False)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    print(investigate("interactions.csv", min_degree=5))
```

case_prompt: Write one concise Python workflow (single code block) from raw CSV interactions to a share-safe graph investigation: ingest data, normalize time, do safe Graphistry auth (env vars), shape edges+nodes, add one degree-like enrichment, run one focused GFQL extraction, apply visual styling, set private privacy mode, and return a non-inline URL.
response_text:
```python
import os
import pandas as pd
import graphistry
from graphistry import n, e_forward

# 1) Ingest raw CSV interactions
df = pd.read_csv("interactions.csv").rename(columns={
    "source": "src", "from": "src",
    "target": "dst", "to": "dst",
    "time": "ts", "timestamp": "ts", "event_time": "ts",
    "interaction_type": "type"
})

required = {"src", "dst", "ts"}
missing = required - set(df.columns)
if missing:
    raise ValueError(f"Missing required columns: {sorted(missing)}")

# 2) Normalize IDs + time
df["src"] = df["src"].astype(str).str.strip()
df["dst"] = df["dst"].astype(str).str.strip()
df = df[(df["src"] != "") & (df["dst"] != "")]
df["ts"] = pd.to_datetime(df["ts"], errors="coerce", utc=True)
df = df.dropna(subset=["ts"]).copy()

# Optional numeric signal if present
if "amount" in df.columns:
    df["amount"] = pd.to_numeric(df["amount"], errors="coerce").fillna(0.0)
else:
    df["amount"] = 1.0

df["type"] = df.get("type", "interaction").fillna("interaction")
df["is_recent"] = df["ts"] >= (pd.Timestamp.now(tz="UTC") - pd.Timedelta(days=14))
df["is_large"] = df["amount"] >= df["amount"].quantile(0.95)

edges = df[["src", "dst", "ts", "type", "amount", "is_recent", "is_large"]].drop_duplicates()

# 3) Shape nodes + degree-like enrichment
node_ids = pd.Index(pd.concat([edges["src"], edges["dst"]]).unique(), name="id")
nodes = pd.DataFrame({"id": node_ids, "type": "entity"})
deg = pd.concat([edges["src"], edges["dst"]]).value_counts().rename_axis("id").reset_index(name="degree")
nodes = nodes.merge(deg, on="id", how="left").fillna({"degree": 0})
hub_cut = max(2, int(nodes["degree"].quantile(0.90)))
nodes["is_hub"] = nodes["degree"] >= hub_cut

# 4) Safe Graphistry auth (env vars only)
if os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_ID") and os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_SECRET"):
    graphistry.register(
        api=3,
        personal_key_id=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_ID"],
        personal_key_secret=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_SECRET"],
    )
elif os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_USERNAME") and os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_PASSWORD"):
    graphistry.register(
        api=3,
        username=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_USERNAME"],
        password=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PASSWORD"],
    )
else:
    raise EnvironmentError(
        "Set either GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_ID + GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_SECRET "
        "or GRAPHISTRY_USERNAME + GRAPHISTRY_PASSWORD"
    )

# 5) Build graph, run focused GFQL extraction (hub -> recent+large edge -> neighbor)
g = graphistry.edges(edges, "src", "dst").nodes(nodes, "id")
g_focus = g.gfql([
    n({"is_hub": True}),
    e_forward(edge_query="is_recent and is_large"),
    n()
])

# 6) Visual styling + privacy-safe share link
g_view = (
    g_focus
    .bind(point_title="id", point_label="id", point_color="type", edge_color="type")
    .encode_point_size("degree")
    .encode_edge_color("amount", palette=["#dbeafe", "#60a5fa", "#1d4ed8"], as_continuous=True)
    .settings(url_params={"info": True, "play": 0})
)

graphistry.privacy(mode="private")
url = g_view.plot(render=False)  # non-inline URL
print(url)
```

```python
import pandas as pd
import graphistry

# graphistry.register(api=3, username="...", password="...")

# 1) Row-oriented events table
events = pd.DataFrame([
    {"event_id": "e1", "event_time": "2026-02-20T01:05:00Z", "user": "alice", "device": "laptop-7", "src_ip": "10.0.0.4", "dst_ip": "52.2.2.2", "process": "powershell.exe", "domain": "cdn.bad.co", "action": "dns"},
    {"event_id": "e2", "event_time": "2026-02-20T01:12:00Z", "user": "alice", "device": "laptop-7", "src_ip": "10.0.0.4", "dst_ip": "52.2.2.2", "process": "curl.exe",       "domain": "cdn.bad.co", "action": "http"},
    {"event_id": "e3", "event_time": "2026-02-20T14:20:00Z", "user": "bob",   "device": "srv-2",    "src_ip": "10.0.2.9", "dst_ip": "8.8.8.8",  "process": "chrome.exe",     "domain": "docs.good.co", "action": "dns"},
    {"event_id": "e4", "event_time": "2026-02-21T02:40:00Z", "user": "alice", "device": "laptop-7", "src_ip": "10.0.0.4", "dst_ip": "23.3.3.3",  "process": "rundll32.exe",   "domain": "drop.bad.co", "action": "http"},
])

# 2) Hypergraph shaping (collapse src/dst IP into one "ip" namespace)
h = graphistry.hypergraph(
    events,
    entity_types=["user", "device", "src_ip", "dst_ip", "process", "domain"],
    opts={
        "EVENTID": "event_id",
        "CATEGORIES": {"ip": ["src_ip", "dst_ip"]},
        "SKIP": ["event_time", "action"],
        "DELIM": "::",
    },
    direct=True,
    drop_na=True,
    return_as="all",
)
g = h["graph"]

# 3) Temporal enrichment on edges + rollups on nodes
nid, src, dst = g._node, g._source, g._destination
e = g._edges.copy()
e["event_ts"] = pd.to_datetime(e["event_time"], utc=True, errors="coerce")
e["event_hour"] = e["event_ts"].dt.floor("h")
e["after_hours"] = (e["event_ts"].dt.hour < 8) | (e["event_ts"].dt.hour > 18)

touches = pd.concat([
    e[[src, "event_ts"]].rename(columns={src: nid}),
    e[[dst, "event_ts"]].rename(columns={dst: nid}),
], ignore_index=True)

n_agg = touches.groupby(nid, as_index=False).agg(
    first_seen=("event_ts", "min"),
    last_seen=("event_ts", "max"),
    touch_count=("event_ts", "count"),
)

n = g.materialize_nodes()._nodes.merge(n_agg, on=nid, how="left")

# 4) Focused traversal from a seed over temporally filtered edges
start = pd.Timestamp("2026-02-20T00:00:00Z")
e_focus = e[(e["event_ts"] >= start) & (e["after_hours"])].copy()
g_focus = g.edges(e_focus).nodes(n, node=nid).hop(
    nodes=pd.DataFrame({nid: ["user::alice"]}),
    hops=2,
    direction="forward",
)

# 5) Static-ish layout + plot
url = (
    g_focus
    .bind(point_title=nid, edge_title="action")
    .encode_point_color("type")
    .encode_edge_color("after_hours")
    .layout_settings(play=0, strong_gravity=True, dissuade_hubs=True, edge_influence=0.2)
    .plot(render=False)
)
print(url)
```

```python
import os
import pandas as pd
import graphistry
from graphistry import n, e_forward

# 1) Auth
graphistry.register(
    api=3,
    personal_key_id=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_ID"],
    personal_key_secret=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_SECRET"]
)
graphistry.privacy(mode="private")

# events: one row per event, e.g. [event_id, ts, user_id, ip, device_id, merchant_id, amount]

# 2) Temporal enrichment (before hypergraph so edge rows inherit it)
events["ts"] = pd.to_datetime(events["ts"], utc=True, errors="coerce")
tmax = events["ts"].max()
events["hour"] = events["ts"].dt.hour
events["day"] = events["ts"].dt.floor("D")
events["recent_48h"] = events["ts"] >= (tmax - pd.Timedelta(hours=48))
events["type"] = "event"  # legend/category-friendly default

# 3) Hypergraph shaping from row columns
hg = graphistry.hypergraph(events, ["user_id", "ip", "device_id", "merchant_id"])
edges = hg["edges"].copy()
nodes = hg["nodes"].copy()
if "type" not in edges.columns:
    edges["type"] = "event_link"
if "type" not in nodes.columns:
    nodes["type"] = "entity"

g = graphistry.edges(edges, "src", "dst").nodes(nodes, "id")

# 4) Focused traversal (GFQL): recent + higher-value links, up to 2 hops
g_focus = g.gfql([
    n(),
    e_forward(edge_query="recent_48h == True and amount >= 500", min_hops=1, max_hops=2),
    n()
])

# 5) Static-ish layout/render settings + plot
(
    g_focus
    .bind(point_label="id", point_color="type", edge_color="type")
    .encode_edge_color("hour", palette=["#1f3b73", "#2a9d8f", "#e9c46a", "#f4a261", "#e76f51"], as_continuous=True)
    .settings(url_params={"play": 0, "info": True})  # pause physics/autoplay for stable view
    .plot()
)
```

response_text:
```python
import graphistry
from graphistry import n, e_forward
from graphistry import Plottable

def remote_heavy_workflow(rg: Plottable) -> str:
    # rg: existing handle already bound to a remote dataset_id
    assert rg._dataset_id, "Expected an existing remote dataset handle"

    node_id = rg._node or "id"
    src = rg._source or "src"
    dst = rg._destination or "dst"

    # Choose a few feature columns you want for AI enrichment
    ai_feature_cols = ["f1", "f2", "f3"]  # replace with real node feature cols

    # 1) Remote trim: return only needed columns
    slim = rg.gfql_remote(
        [n(), e_forward(), n()],
        node_col_subset=[node_id, "type", *ai_feature_cols],
        edge_col_subset=[src, dst, "type"],
        output_type="all",
        engine="auto",
        persist=True
    )

    # 2) Remote graph-AI enrichment: UMAP + DBSCAN labels (_dbscan)
    enriched = slim.python_remote_g(
        code=f"""
from graphistry import Plottable
def task(g: Plottable):
    g = g.materialize_nodes()
    return g.umap(kind='nodes', X={ai_feature_cols!r}, dbscan=True, engine='auto')
""",
        output_type="all",
        engine="cudf",
        validate=False
    )

    # 3) Second focused remote extraction: outlier-centered neighborhood
    focused = enriched.gfql_remote(
        [n({"_dbscan": -1}), e_forward(min_hops=1, max_hops=2), n()],
        node_col_subset=[node_id, "type", "_dbscan"],
        edge_col_subset=[src, dst, "type"],
        output_type="all",
        engine="auto",
        persist=True
    )

    # 4) Style + non-public, non-inline URL
    styled = (
        focused
        .bind(point_color="_dbscan", edge_color="type")
        .settings(url_params={"play": 0, "info": True})
    )

    graphistry.privacy(mode="private")
    return styled.plot(render=False)  # URL string (not inline)
```

case_prompt: Give a short pipeline for pulling interactions via a connector path (Neo4j or Splunk) with dataframe fallback, shaping edges/nodes, enriching one metric, extracting a focused subgraph, styling, and plotting a non-public non-inline URL. If auth appears, keep it safe.
response_text:
Using skills: `pygraphistry-connectors` -> `pygraphistry-core` -> `pygraphistry-gfql` -> `pygraphistry-visualization`.

```python
import os
import pandas as pd
import graphistry
from graphistry import n, e_forward

# 1) Safe auth (no hardcoded secrets)
graphistry.register(
    api=3,
    personal_key_id=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_ID"],
    personal_key_secret=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_SECRET"],
)

# 2) Pull interactions via connector path, fallback to dataframe
source = os.getenv("SOURCE", "neo4j")  # neo4j | splunk
try:
    if source == "neo4j":
        from neo4j import GraphDatabase
        q = """
        MATCH (a)-[r:INTERACTS_WITH]->(b)
        RETURN toString(id(a)) AS src, toString(id(b)) AS dst, coalesce(r.weight, 1.0) AS weight
        """
        with GraphDatabase.driver(
            os.environ["NEO4J_URI"],
            auth=(os.environ["NEO4J_USER"], os.environ["NEO4J_PASSWORD"]),
        ) as drv:
            with drv.session() as s:
                edges_df = pd.DataFrame([rec.data() for rec in s.run(q)])
    else:  # splunk
        import splunklib.client as splunk_client
        import splunklib.results as splunk_results
        svc = splunk_client.connect(
            host=os.environ["SPLUNK_HOST"],
            port=int(os.getenv("SPLUNK_PORT", "8089")),
            token=os.environ["SPLUNK_TOKEN"],
        )
        rr = svc.jobs.oneshot("search index=interactions | stats count as weight by src dst")
        edges_df = pd.DataFrame([r for r in splunk_results.ResultsReader(rr) if isinstance(r, dict)])
except Exception:
    edges_df = pd.read_parquet("data/interactions.parquet")  # dataframe fallback

# 3) Shape edges/nodes + enrich one metric (degree)
edges_df = edges_df[["src", "dst", "weight"]].copy()
edges_df["type"] = "interaction"
ids = pd.Index(pd.concat([edges_df["src"], edges_df["dst"]]).unique(), name="id")
nodes_df = ids.to_frame(index=False)
deg = pd.concat([edges_df["src"], edges_df["dst"]]).value_counts()
nodes_df["degree"] = nodes_df["id"].map(deg).fillna(0).astype(int)
nodes_df["hot"] = nodes_df["degree"] >= nodes_df["degree"].quantile(0.95)
nodes_df["type"] = "entity"

g = graphistry.edges(edges_df, "src", "dst").nodes(nodes_df, "id")

# 4) Extract focused subgraph (hot nodes, up to 2 hops)
g_focus = g.gfql([n({"hot": True}), e_forward(max_hops=2), n()]).name("hot-2hop")

# 5) Style + plot as non-public, non-inline URL
graphistry.privacy(mode="private")
url = (
    g_focus
    .bind(point_label="id", point_size="degree", edge_color="weight")
    .encode_point_color("hot", categorical_mapping={True: "#d62728", False: "#9aa0a6"})
    .encode_edge_color("weight", palette=["#cfe8ff", "#004b8d"], as_continuous=True)
    .settings(url_params={"play": 0, "info": True})
    .plot(render=False)   # URL only, no inline render
)
print(url)
```

case_prompt: In 4 concise bullets, explain connector choice for Neo4j and Splunk, and include a dataframe-first fallback path.
response_text:
- Use the **Neo4j connector** when Neo4j is your system of record and you need graph-native semantics (Cypher, typed relationships, multi-hop traversals) directly from a property graph.  
- Use the **Splunk connector** when your source is operational/security telemetry and you want to turn SPL search results into investigation graphs quickly.  
- Practical routing rule: pick the connector closest to where truth already lives (Neo4j for modeled entity-relationship graphs, Splunk for time-series/event pipelines), then normalize into common node/edge columns.  
- **Dataframe-first fallback**: if connectors are blocked/unavailable, pull data via native clients/API/export into `pandas` DataFrames (`edges_df`, `nodes_df`) and proceed with `graphistry.edges(edges_df, "src", "dst").nodes(nodes_df, "id")` so the visualization/analysis path stays unchanged.

case_prompt: In 4 concise bullets, explain connector choice for Neo4j and Splunk, and include a dataframe-first fallback path.
response_text:
- Use the **Neo4j connector path** when relationship logic is graph-native (multi-hop traversal, Cypher pattern matching): run Cypher upstream, return edge/node tables, then bind in PyGraphistry.
- Use the **Splunk connector path** when data is SIEM/log-centric (events, alerts, entities): run SPL upstream to extract correlated entities/links, then convert results into edge/node tables.
- Prefer a **source-native query → dataframe → `edges()/nodes()`** workflow for both: it is the safest default, keeps auth/query semantics in each system, and scales better when you pre-filter upstream.
- **Dataframe-first fallback** if connector setup is blocked: export/query into pandas (`src`, `dst`, optional node `id` + attributes), then do `graphistry.edges(df, 'src', 'dst').nodes(nodes_df, 'id').plot()` with credentials from environment variables.

case_prompt: Give exactly 3 concise bullets on schema hygiene for Graphistry visuals: singleton type columns, avoiding dotted names, and native datetime usage.
response_text:
- Keep each column’s values to a **single data type** (no mixed ints/strings/null-like text) so Graphistry infers encodings and analytics consistently.
- **Avoid dotted column names** (for example, `user.id`); normalize to flat names like `user_id` to prevent parser/selector ambiguity.
- Use **native datetime dtypes** (`datetime64[ns]` / timezone-aware datetimes) instead of strings when possible for correct time parsing, filtering, and timeline visuals.

case_prompt: Give exactly 3 concise bullets on schema hygiene for Graphistry visuals: singleton type columns, avoiding dotted names, and native datetime usage.
response_text:
- Keep one plain `type` column on both nodes and edges so legends and default categorical encodings stay stable.
- Avoid dotted column names like `node.type` or `edge.type`; use flat names instead.
- Use native datetime columns (not strings) for accurate time encodings and time-sliced comparisons.

case_prompt: A novice fraud analyst only has a transactions table. Provide one concise Python workflow from raw table data to a share-safe graph: include table ingest, safe auth setup, graph shaping, one enrichment metric, one focused subgraph extraction step, one styling encode call, and a non-inline plot URL.
response_text:
```python
# pip install pandas graphistry
import os, hashlib
import pandas as pd
import graphistry

# 1) Table ingest (raw transactions table)
# expected columns: tx_id, src_account, dst_account, amount, ts, channel
tx = pd.read_csv("transactions.csv")

# 2) Safe auth setup (no secrets in code)
graphistry.register(
    api=3,
    protocol="https",
    server=os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_SERVER", "hub.graphistry.com"),
    personal_key_id=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_KEY_ID"],
    personal_key_secret=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_KEY_SECRET"],
)

# 3) Graph shaping + share-safe anonymization
anon = lambda v: hashlib.sha256(str(v).encode()).hexdigest()[:16]
edges = tx.assign(
    src=tx["src_account"].map(anon),
    dst=tx["dst_account"].map(anon),
    amount_usd=tx["amount"].astype(float),
)[["tx_id", "src", "dst", "amount_usd", "ts", "channel"]]

# 4) One enrichment metric: per-node total transacted amount
nodes = pd.concat([
    edges[["src", "amount_usd"]].rename(columns={"src": "id"}),
    edges[["dst", "amount_usd"]].rename(columns={"dst": "id"}),
]).groupby("id", as_index=False)["amount_usd"].sum().rename(columns={"amount_usd": "tx_volume"})

# 5) Focused subgraph extraction: keep edges touching top 1% high-volume nodes
cutoff = nodes["tx_volume"].quantile(0.99)
hot = set(nodes.loc[nodes["tx_volume"] >= cutoff, "id"])
sub_edges = edges[edges["src"].isin(hot) | edges["dst"].isin(hot)]
sub_nodes = nodes[nodes["id"].isin(pd.unique(sub_edges[["src", "dst"]].values.ravel()))]

# 6) One styling encode call
g = (graphistry
     .bind(source="src", destination="dst", node="id")
     .edges(sub_edges)
     .nodes(sub_nodes)
     .encode_point_color("tx_volume"))

# 7) Non-inline plot URL (share-safe link target)
url = g.plot(render=False)
print(url)
```

case_prompt: A novice fraud analyst only has a transactions table. Provide one concise Python workflow from raw table data to a share-safe graph: include table ingest, safe auth setup, graph shaping, one enrichment metric, one focused subgraph extraction step, one styling encode call, and a non-inline plot URL.
response_text:
Using `pygraphistry-core` + `pygraphistry-gfql` + `pygraphistry-visualization` for secure auth, focused subgraphing, and share-safe plotting.

```python
import os
import pandas as pd
import graphistry
from graphistry import n, e_forward

# 1) Ingest raw transactions table
tx = pd.read_csv("transactions.csv")  # columns like: from_account,to_account,amount,timestamp
tx = tx.rename(columns={"from_account": "src", "to_account": "dst"})
tx = tx.dropna(subset=["src", "dst", "amount"]).copy()
tx["timestamp"] = pd.to_datetime(tx["timestamp"], errors="coerce")
tx["type"] = "transaction"

# 2) One enrichment metric: per-account outbound transaction count
nodes = pd.DataFrame({"id": pd.unique(pd.concat([tx["src"], tx["dst"]], ignore_index=True))})
nodes["type"] = "account"
out_counts = tx.groupby("src").size().rename("out_txn_count")
nodes = nodes.merge(out_counts, left_on="id", right_index=True, how="left").fillna({"out_txn_count": 0})

# Helper flag for focused extraction
tx["high_value"] = tx["amount"] >= tx["amount"].quantile(0.95)

# 3) Safe auth setup (env vars only; no hardcoded secrets)
graphistry.register(
    api=3,
    personal_key_id=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_ID"],
    personal_key_secret=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_SECRET"]
)
graphistry.privacy(mode="private")  # share-safe default

# 4) Graph shaping
g = graphistry.edges(tx, "src", "dst").nodes(nodes, "id")

# 5) Focused subgraph extraction: only high-value transaction edges
g_focus = g.gfql([n(), e_forward({"high_value": True}, min_hops=1, max_hops=1), n()])

# 6) One styling encode call
g_style = g_focus.encode_point_size("out_txn_count")

# 7) Non-inline plot URL
plot_url = g_style.plot(render=False)
print("Share-safe plot URL:", plot_url)
```

case_prompt: Provide a concise connector-oriented workflow for Neo4j or Splunk with a dataframe-first fallback: mention connector choice, include explicit edges(...).nodes(...) shaping, run one GFQL filter using explicit .gfql([...]) (not chain()/hop()), set privacy mode (private or organization), and produce plot(render=False). If auth is shown, use environment variables only (no username/password string literals). Return one compact code block with minimal prose.
response_text:
```python
import os
import pandas as pd
import graphistry
from graphistry import n, e_forward
from neo4j import GraphDatabase

# Connector choice: Neo4j (dataframe-first fallback on failure)
try:
    driver = GraphDatabase.driver(
        os.environ["NEO4J_URI"],
        auth=(os.environ["NEO4J_USER"], os.environ["NEO4J_PASSWORD"]),
    )
    session_kwargs = {"database": os.environ["NEO4J_DATABASE"]} if os.environ.get("NEO4J_DATABASE") else {}
    with driver.session(**session_kwargs) as s:
        edges_df = pd.DataFrame(
            s.run("""
                MATCH (a)-[r]->(b)
                RETURN coalesce(a.id, toString(id(a))) AS src,
                       coalesce(b.id, toString(id(b))) AS dst,
                       coalesce(r.amount, 0.0) AS amount
                LIMIT 50000
            """).data()
        )
    driver.close()
except Exception:
    edges_df = pd.DataFrame({
        "src": ["acct_1", "acct_2", "acct_3"],
        "dst": ["acct_2", "acct_3", "acct_4"],
        "amount": [1500.0, 200.0, 3200.0],
    })

nodes_df = pd.DataFrame({"id": pd.unique(pd.concat([edges_df["src"], edges_df["dst"]], ignore_index=True))})

graphistry.register(
    api=3,
    personal_key_id=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_ID"],
    personal_key_secret=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_SECRET"],
    org_name=os.environ.get("GRAPHISTRY_ORG_NAME"),
)

g = graphistry.edges(edges_df, "src", "dst").nodes(nodes_df, "id")
g_filtered = g.gfql([n(), e_forward(edge_query="amount >= 1000"), n()])
graphistry.privacy(mode="private")
plot_url = g_filtered.plot(render=False)
print(plot_url)
```

case_prompt: Give exactly 5 concise bullets for troubleshooting Graphistry org/API key auth issues in PyGraphistry, including api=3, server/protocol, org_name, and personal key env vars.
response_text:
- Use `graphistry.register(api=3, ...)` explicitly; many org/key flows fail when code falls back to older auth modes.
- Confirm endpoint settings match your tenant: `protocol='https'` and correct `server` (for example `hub.graphistry.com` vs your private host).
- Verify `org_name` is the exact org slug/case expected by the server, and that your user/key is actually a member of that org.
- Check personal key env vars are set in the active shell/process with no typos/whitespace: `GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_ID` + `GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_SECRET` (or `GRAPHISTRY_API_KEY` where configured).
- Reproduce with a minimal script using only env vars, then rotate/regenerate the key if auth still fails (expired/revoked keys are a common root cause).

case_prompt: Give exactly 5 concise bullets for troubleshooting Graphistry org/API key auth issues in PyGraphistry, including api=3, server/protocol, org_name, and personal key env vars.
response_text:
- Use `graphistry.register(api=3, ...)` explicitly; mismatched API version is a common auth failure.
- Confirm endpoint settings: `GRAPHISTRY_SERVER` (e.g., `hub.graphistry.com`) and `GRAPHISTRY_PROTOCOL` (`https`); wrong host/protocol breaks login before creds are checked.
- For org-routed auth, pass `org_name` (often `os.environ['GRAPHISTRY_ORG_NAME']`) and, if needed, `idp_name`; missing/incorrect org causes valid creds to fail.
- For API/personal key auth, set `GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_ID` and `GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_SECRET`, then call `register(api=3, personal_key_id=..., personal_key_secret=...)`.
- Don’t mix auth modes in one call (username/password vs org SSO vs personal key); print non-secret config values to verify which path your process is actually using.

```python
import os
import pandas as pd
import graphistry

# Safe auth: use env vars (prefer personal key pair; fallback to username/password)
server = os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_SERVER", "hub.graphistry.com")
if os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_ID") and os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_SECRET"):
    graphistry.register(
        api=3,
        server=server,
        protocol="https",
        personal_key_id=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_ID"],
        personal_key_secret=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_SECRET"],
    )
else:
    graphistry.register(
        api=3,
        server=server,
        protocol="https",
        username=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_USERNAME"],
        password=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PASSWORD"],
    )

# Tiny tables
edges = pd.DataFrame({
    "src": ["A", "A", "B"],
    "dst": ["B", "C", "C"],
    "weight": [1, 2, 3],
})
nodes = pd.DataFrame({
    "id": ["A", "B", "C"],
    "label": ["Alpha", "Beta", "Gamma"],
    "group": ["x", "x", "y"],
})

# Build + plot
(
    graphistry
    .edges(edges, "src", "dst")
    .nodes(nodes, "id")
    .bind(point_label="label", point_color="group", edge_weight="weight")
    .plot()
)
```

```python
import pandas as pd
import graphistry

# Row-oriented records
rows = pd.DataFrame([
    {"actor": "alice", "event": "login",    "location": "nyc"},
    {"actor": "bob",   "event": "download", "location": "sf"},
])

# 1) Convert wide rows -> graph (actor/event/location become typed nodes)
hg = graphistry.hypergraph(rows, ["actor", "event", "location"])
g = hg["graph"]  # Plotter with edges/nodes from the hypergraph transform

# 2) Prepare for node-centric operations (ensures explicit node table exists)
g_nodes = g.materialize_nodes()

# Now safe to do node-centric steps (bindings/AI/features/etc.) and plot
g_nodes.bind(point_color="type", point_title="id").plot()
```

Use `GFQL` (`g.gfql([...])`) instead when you need multi-step pattern logic, named steps + cross-step constraints (`where=[...]`), richer predicates/temporal filters, or remote execution (`gfql_remote`).

```python
import graphistry

    graphistry
```

case_prompt: In 3-5 bullets, explain connector strategy for Neo4j vs Splunk and include a dataframe-first fallback path.
response_text:
- **Neo4j connector strategy:** Treat Neo4j as a native graph source; push graph shaping into Cypher (server-side filtering/projection), and return stable `nodes`/`edges` tables with explicit IDs, labels, and relationship types. This keeps traversal logic in Neo4j and minimizes client-side reshaping.  
- **Splunk connector strategy:** Treat Splunk as an event source first; use SPL to narrow time/window/context, then derive entities and links (for example via `stats`, co-occurrence, sessionization) before graphing. More normalization is typically needed than with Neo4j.  
- **Operational difference:** Neo4j is schema-forward and relationship-explicit, so connector logic is mostly query + mapping; Splunk is semi-structured and time-centric, so connector logic is mostly extraction + entity resolution + edge construction.  
- **Dataframe-first fallback path:** If direct connectors are unavailable, pull tabular results with native clients (`neo4j` Python driver or Splunk SDK/REST), build canonical `nodes_df`/`edges_df` in pandas, then render via Graphistry (`g = graphistry.bind(...).nodes(nodes_df).edges(edges_df)`). This gives one common pipeline across both sources.

case_prompt: In 3-5 bullets, explain connector strategy for Neo4j vs Splunk and include a dataframe-first fallback path.
response_text:
- **Neo4j strategy:** Keep graph logic upstream in Cypher when you need multi-hop traversals/pattern matching, then pull the result into PyGraphistry for rendering (`cypher`/connector flow is the primary path).
- **Splunk strategy:** Treat Splunk as a log/SIEM source; do SPL search + field extraction first, shape events into edge/node tables, then bind in PyGraphistry (tabular-first ingestion is typically best here).
- **DataFrame-first fallback (works for both):** If connector setup/auth is blocked or query semantics are unclear, run source-native query -> pandas DataFrame(s) (`edges_df`, optional `nodes_df`) -> `graphistry.edges(...).nodes(...)` -> plot.
- **Operational rule:** For either source, push heavy filtering/aggregation upstream before plotting, and keep all connector/Graphistry credentials in environment variables or secret stores (no hardcoded keys).

case_prompt: An analyst is investigating coordinated social-media claim reuse. Provide one concise Python workflow from a posts table to a share-safe claim-reuse network: normalize claims, compute reuse frequency, represent users/claims as graph entities, apply risk-oriented styling, and return a non-inline share URL.
response_text:
```python
import re
import pandas as pd
import graphistry

# posts: DataFrame with at least ['post_id', 'user_id', 'claim_text']
def claim_reuse_share_url(posts: pd.DataFrame) -> str:
    graphistry.register(
        username="YOUR_USERNAME",
        password="YOUR_PASSWORD",
        server="hub.graphistry.com",
        protocol="https",
    )
    graphistry.privacy(mode="private", notify=False)  # share-safe default

    # 1) Normalize claims
    def norm_claim(s: str) -> str:
        s = (s or "").lower()
        s = re.sub(r"http\S+|www\.\S+", " ", s)      # remove URLs
        s = re.sub(r"[^a-z0-9\s]", " ", s)           # strip punctuation
        s = re.sub(r"\s+", " ", s).strip()           # collapse spaces
        return s

    df = posts.copy()
    df["claim_norm"] = df["claim_text"].map(norm_claim)
    df = df[df["claim_norm"] != ""]

    # 2) Compute reuse frequency
    claim_freq = (
        df.groupby("claim_norm", as_index=False)
          .agg(reuse_posts=("post_id", "nunique"),
               reuse_users=("user_id", "nunique"))
    )

    # 3) Build user->claim graph entities
    edges = (
        df.groupby(["user_id", "claim_norm"], as_index=False)
          .agg(reuse_by_user=("post_id", "count"))
          .merge(claim_freq, on="claim_norm", how="left")
          .rename(columns={"user_id": "src", "claim_norm": "dst"})
    )
    edges["src"] = "user:" + edges["src"].astype(str)
    edges["dst"] = "claim:" + edges["dst"]

    users = pd.DataFrame({"id": edges["src"].unique(), "kind": "user"})
    claims = claim_freq.copy()
    claims["id"] = "claim:" + claims["claim_norm"]
    claims["kind"] = "claim"
    claims["risk"] = pd.cut(
        claims["reuse_users"],
        bins=[-1, 1, 3, 10**9],
        labels=["low", "medium", "high"]
    ).astype(str)
    claims["color"] = claims["risk"].map({"low": "#9AA0A6", "medium": "#F9AB00", "high": "#D93025"})
    users["color"] = "#1A73E8"

    nodes = pd.concat(
        [users[["id", "kind", "color"]],
         claims[["id", "kind", "risk", "reuse_users", "reuse_posts", "color"]]],
        ignore_index=True
    )

    # 4) Risk-oriented styling + 5) return non-inline share URL
    g = (
        graphistry
        .nodes(nodes)
        .edges(edges)
        .bind(source="src", destination="dst", node="id",
              point_color="color", point_size="reuse_users",
              edge_weight="reuse_by_user")
    )
    return g.plot(render=False)  # URL string, not inline

# usage:
# url = claim_reuse_share_url(posts_df)
# print(url)
```

case_prompt: An analyst is investigating coordinated social-media claim reuse. Provide one concise Python workflow from a posts table to a share-safe claim-reuse network: normalize claims, compute reuse frequency, represent users/claims as graph entities, apply risk-oriented styling, and return a non-inline share URL.
response_text:
Using `pygraphistry-core` + `pygraphistry-visualization` for table-to-graph construction, risk styling, and private share-link output.

```python
import os
import re
import pandas as pd
import graphistry

# posts_df columns expected: post_id, user_id, claim_text, ts (optional)

# 1) Register + privacy (share-safe)
graphistry.register(
    api=3,
    username=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_USERNAME"],
    password=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PASSWORD"],
)
graphistry.privacy(mode="private")  # or "organization"

# 2) Normalize claims
def normalize_claim(s: str) -> str:
    s = "" if pd.isna(s) else str(s).lower().strip()
    s = re.sub(r"http\S+|www\.\S+", " ", s)      # strip URLs
    s = re.sub(r"[^a-z0-9\s]", " ", s)           # strip punctuation
    s = re.sub(r"\s+", " ", s).strip()           # collapse whitespace
    return s

posts = posts_df.copy()
posts["claim_norm"] = posts["claim_text"].map(normalize_claim)
posts = posts[posts["claim_norm"] != ""]

# 3) Compute reuse frequency per normalized claim
reuse = posts.groupby("claim_norm", as_index=False).agg(
    reuse_count=("post_id", "count"),
    unique_users=("user_id", "nunique")
)

posts = posts.merge(reuse, on="claim_norm", how="left")
posts["claim_id"] = "claim:" + posts["claim_norm"].map(lambda x: str(abs(hash(x))))

# 4) Graph entities: users + claims; edges = user reuses claim
edges = (
    posts.groupby(["user_id", "claim_id", "claim_norm"], as_index=False)
    .agg(reuse_by_user=("post_id", "count"), reuse_count=("reuse_count", "max"))
    .rename(columns={"user_id": "src", "claim_id": "dst"})
)
edges["type"] = "reuses_claim"

claim_nodes = (
    posts[["claim_id", "claim_norm", "reuse_count", "unique_users"]]
    .drop_duplicates("claim_id")
    .rename(columns={"claim_id": "id"})
)
claim_nodes["type"] = "claim"
claim_nodes["risk_level"] = pd.cut(
    claim_nodes["reuse_count"],
    bins=[-1, 1, 4, 999999],
    labels=["low", "medium", "high"]
)

user_nodes = posts[["user_id"]].drop_duplicates().rename(columns={"user_id": "id"})
user_nodes["type"] = "user"
user_nodes["risk_level"] = "low"

nodes = pd.concat([user_nodes, claim_nodes], ignore_index=True, sort=False)

# 5) Risk-oriented styling + non-inline share URL
g = graphistry.edges(edges, "src", "dst").nodes(nodes, "id")
g2 = (
    g.bind(
        point_title="type",
        point_label="id",
        point_color="risk_level",
        edge_color="reuse_count"
    )
    .encode_point_color(
        "risk_level",
        categorical_mapping={"low": "#94a3b8", "medium": "#f59e0b", "high": "#dc2626"},
        default_mapping="#64748b"
    )
    .encode_edge_color(
        "reuse_count",
        palette=["#bfdbfe", "#60a5fa", "#1d4ed8"],
        as_continuous=True
    )
    .encode_point_size("reuse_count")
    .settings(url_params={"info": True, "play": 0})
)

share_url = g2.plot(render=False)   # <- non-inline share URL string
print(share_url)
```

case_prompt: Provide a compact connector triage snippet for an analyst using Neo4j or Splunk with a dataframe fallback. Explain connector choice, shape a graph, set non-public privacy mode (private or organization), and return a non-inline URL with plot(render=False). Keep auth/privacy handling safe.
response_text:
Use this triage pattern:

- `Neo4j`: choose when relationship logic is best pushed into Cypher.
- `Splunk`: choose when starting from SIEM/SPL search results.
- `DataFrame`: fallback when connector access is unavailable or data is already tabular.

```python
import os
import pandas as pd
import graphistry

SOURCE = os.getenv("GRAPH_SOURCE", "dataframe").lower()   # neo4j | splunk | dataframe
PRIVACY_MODE = os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_PRIVACY_MODE", "private").lower()  # private | organization
if PRIVACY_MODE not in {"private", "organization"}:
    raise ValueError("GRAPHISTRY_PRIVACY_MODE must be 'private' or 'organization'")

# Safe auth: env vars only, no hardcoded secrets
graphistry.register(
    api=3,
    personal_key_id=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_ID"],
    personal_key_secret=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_SECRET"],
    org_name=os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_ORG_NAME")
)

def load_edges():
    if SOURCE == "neo4j":
        from neo4j import GraphDatabase
        q = os.getenv("NEO4J_EDGE_QUERY",
            "MATCH (a)-[r]->(b) RETURN toString(id(a)) AS src, toString(id(b)) AS dst, type(r) AS type")
        with GraphDatabase.driver(
            os.environ["NEO4J_URI"],
            auth=(os.environ["NEO4J_USER"], os.environ["NEO4J_PASSWORD"])
        ).session(database=os.getenv("NEO4J_DATABASE")) as s:
            return pd.DataFrame([row.data() for row in s.run(q)])
    if SOURCE == "splunk":
        import splunklib.client as client
        import splunklib.results as results
        svc = client.connect(
            host=os.environ["SPLUNK_HOST"],
            port=int(os.getenv("SPLUNK_PORT", "8089")),
            token=os.environ["SPLUNK_TOKEN"],
            scheme=os.getenv("SPLUNK_SCHEME", "https"),
        )
        search = os.getenv("SPLUNK_SEARCH",
            "search index=* | eval src=coalesce(src,source), dst=coalesce(dst,dest) | table src dst")
        stream = svc.jobs.oneshot(search, output_mode="json")
        return pd.DataFrame([r for r in results.ResultsReader(stream) if isinstance(r, dict)])
    return edges_df  # dataframe fallback provided by analyst session

edges = load_edges().dropna(subset=["src", "dst"]).copy()
edges["src"] = edges["src"].astype(str)
edges["dst"] = edges["dst"].astype(str)
if "type" not in edges.columns:
    edges["type"] = "relation"

nodes = pd.DataFrame({"id": pd.unique(edges[["src", "dst"]].to_numpy().ravel())})
g = graphistry.edges(edges, "src", "dst").nodes(nodes, "id")

graphistry.privacy(mode=PRIVACY_MODE)   # non-public only
plot_url = g.name("connector-triage").plot(render=False)  # URL, no inline render
print(plot_url)
```

case_prompt: Provide a compact connector triage snippet for an analyst using Neo4j or Splunk with a dataframe fallback. Explain connector choice, shape a graph, set non-public privacy mode (private or organization), and return a non-inline URL with plot(render=False). Keep auth/privacy handling safe.
response_text:
Use `pygraphistry-connectors` triage: Neo4j for graph-native traversal, Splunk for SIEM/log search, otherwise fall back to an existing dataframe.

```python
import os
import pandas as pd
import graphistry

def triage_plot(connector: str, privacy_mode: str = "private", fallback_edges: pd.DataFrame | None = None) -> str:
    # Safe Graphistry auth: env vars only
    graphistry.register(
        api=3,
        org_name=os.environ.get("GRAPHISTRY_ORG_NAME"),  # optional but recommended for org routing
        personal_key_id=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_ID"],
        personal_key_secret=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_SECRET"],
    )
    if privacy_mode not in {"private", "organization"}:
        raise ValueError("privacy_mode must be 'private' or 'organization'")
    graphistry.privacy(mode=privacy_mode)  # non-public mode

    connector = connector.lower().strip()
    if connector == "neo4j":
        from neo4j import GraphDatabase
        cypher = os.environ.get(
            "NEO4J_CYPHER",
            "MATCH (a)-[r]->(b) RETURN toString(id(a)) AS src, toString(id(b)) AS dst, type(r) AS rel LIMIT 5000"
        )
        with GraphDatabase.driver(
            os.environ["NEO4J_URI"],
            auth=(os.environ["NEO4J_USER"], os.environ["NEO4J_PASSWORD"])
        ) as drv:
            rows = drv.execute_query(cypher).records
            edges_df = pd.DataFrame([dict(r) for r in rows])

    elif connector == "splunk":
        import splunklib.client as splunk_client
        import splunklib.results as splunk_results
        svc = splunk_client.connect(
            host=os.environ["SPLUNK_HOST"],
            port=int(os.environ.get("SPLUNK_PORT", "8089")),
            username=os.environ["SPLUNK_USER"],
            password=os.environ["SPLUNK_PASSWORD"],
        )
        search = os.environ.get(
            "SPLUNK_SEARCH",
            'search index=* | head 5000 | eval src=coalesce(src, host), dst=coalesce(dst, sourcetype) | table src dst'
        )
        rr = splunk_results.ResultsReader(svc.jobs.oneshot(search, output_mode="json"))
        edges_df = pd.DataFrame([r for r in rr if isinstance(r, dict)])

    else:
        if fallback_edges is None:
            raise ValueError("Provide fallback_edges dataframe when connector is not 'neo4j' or 'splunk'")
        edges_df = fallback_edges.copy()

    # Shape graph + return non-inline URL
    g = graphistry.edges(edges_df, "src", "dst")
    return g.plot(render=False)

# Example:
# url = triage_plot("neo4j", privacy_mode="organization")
# print(url)
```

Connector choice rule of thumb:
- `neo4j`: use when pattern/traversal is best expressed in Cypher.
- `splunk`: use when source is operational/security logs.
- fallback dataframe: use when data is already extracted/tabular.

```python
import pandas as pd
import graphistry

# 1) Auth (set these in env vars or replace inline)
graphistry.register(api=3, username="YOUR_USER", password="YOUR_PASSWORD")

# 2) Ingest raw tabular ops records (example: shipment legs)
raw = pd.read_csv(
    "shipment_legs.csv",
    parse_dates=["depart_ts", "arrive_ts"]
)
# Expected columns:
# shipment_id, origin_hub, destination_hub, carrier, depart_ts, arrive_ts, units

# 3) Light ETL shaping
df = (
    raw.dropna(subset=["origin_hub", "destination_hub", "depart_ts", "arrive_ts"])
       .assign(
           origin_hub=lambda d: d.origin_hub.str.strip().str.upper(),
           destination_hub=lambda d: d.destination_hub.str.strip().str.upper(),
           transit_hours=lambda d: (d.arrive_ts - d.depart_ts).dt.total_seconds() / 3600
       )
       .query("origin_hub != destination_hub")
)

# 4) Edge table + metric enrichment (one metric: avg transit time per route)
edges = (
    df.groupby(["origin_hub", "destination_hub"], as_index=False)
      .agg(
          trips=("shipment_id", "nunique"),
          total_units=("units", "sum"),
          avg_transit_hours=("transit_hours", "mean")   # metric enrichment
      )
      .rename(columns={"origin_hub": "src", "destination_hub": "dst"})
)

# Optional node shaping
nodes = pd.DataFrame({"id": pd.unique(edges[["src", "dst"]].values.ravel("K"))})
out_units = edges.groupby("src", as_index=False)["total_units"].sum().rename(columns={"src": "id"})
nodes = nodes.merge(out_units, on="id", how="left").fillna({"total_units": 0})

# 5) Graphistry binding + non-inline plot URL
g = (
    graphistry.bind(
        source="src",
        destination="dst",
        edge_weight="total_units",
        edge_title="avg_transit_hours",
        point_title="id",
        point_size="total_units"
    )
    .nodes(nodes)
    .edges(edges)
)

plot_url = g.plot(render=False)   # non-inline URL
print("Graphistry URL:", plot_url)
```

case_prompt: For a non-fraud, non-cyber operations dataset, provide an end-to-end Python workflow from raw tabular records to a Graphistry visualization. Include pandas ingest, light ETL shaping, graph binding, one metric enrichment, and a non-inline plot URL. Keep it concise.
response_text:
```python
# pip install pandas graphistry
import os
import pandas as pd
import graphistry

# 1) Auth
graphistry.register(
    api=3,
    username=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_USERNAME"],
    password=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PASSWORD"],
)
graphistry.privacy(mode="private")  # or "organization"/"public"

# 2) Ingest raw tabular ops records (example: supply-chain movements)
raw = pd.read_csv("shipments.csv")
# Expected columns: shipment_id, supplier_id, warehouse_id, item_id, quantity, ship_ts

# 3) Light ETL shaping
df = (
    raw.rename(columns={"supplier_id": "src", "warehouse_id": "dst", "quantity": "qty"})
       .dropna(subset=["src", "dst"])
       .assign(
           src=lambda x: x["src"].astype(str).str.strip(),
           dst=lambda x: x["dst"].astype(str).str.strip(),
           qty=lambda x: pd.to_numeric(x["qty"], errors="coerce").fillna(0),
           type="shipment",
       )
)

# Aggregate repeated movements
edges = (
    df.groupby(["src", "dst", "type"], as_index=False)
      .agg(qty_total=("qty", "sum"), shipments=("shipment_id", "nunique"))
)

# 4) Node table + one metric enrichment (degree)
nodes = pd.DataFrame({"id": pd.unique(pd.concat([edges["src"], edges["dst"]], ignore_index=True))})
nodes["type"] = nodes["id"].where(nodes["id"].str.startswith("SUP"), "warehouse").replace(
    {nodes["id"]: "supplier"} if False else {}
)
# robust type assignment:
nodes["type"] = nodes["id"].apply(lambda v: "supplier" if v.startswith("SUP") else "warehouse")

deg = pd.concat(
    [edges[["src"]].rename(columns={"src": "id"}), edges[["dst"]].rename(columns={"dst": "id"})],
    ignore_index=True,
).value_counts("id").rename("degree").reset_index()
nodes = nodes.merge(deg, on="id", how="left").fillna({"degree": 0})

# 5) Bind + visualize
g = (
    graphistry.edges(edges, "src", "dst")
    .nodes(nodes, "id")
    .bind(
        point_label="id",
        point_color="type",
        point_size="degree",
        edge_title="type",
    )
)

# 6) Non-inline plot URL
plot_url = g.plot(render=False)
print(plot_url)
```

case_prompt: Write one concise Python workflow (single code block) from raw CSV interactions to a share-safe graph investigation: ingest data, normalize time, do safe Graphistry auth (env vars), shape edges+nodes, add one degree-like enrichment, run one focused GFQL extraction, apply visual styling, set private privacy mode, and return a non-inline URL.
response_text:
```python
import os
import pandas as pd
import graphistry
from graphistry import n, e_forward

# 1) Ingest raw CSV interactions + normalize schema/time
csv_path = os.getenv("INTERACTIONS_CSV", "interactions.csv")
df = pd.read_csv(csv_path)

df = df.rename(columns={"source": "src", "from": "src", "actor": "src", "target": "dst", "to": "dst", "object": "dst"})
if not {"src", "dst", "event_time"}.issubset(df.columns):
    raise ValueError("CSV must include src/dst/event_time (or common aliases like source/target, actor/object).")

df["event_time"] = pd.to_datetime(df["event_time"], utc=True, errors="coerce")
df = df.dropna(subset=["src", "dst", "event_time"]).copy()
df["src"] = df["src"].astype(str).str.strip()
df["dst"] = df["dst"].astype(str).str.strip()
df["event_type"] = df["event_type"] if "event_type" in df.columns else "interaction"
df["outcome"] = df["outcome"] if "outcome" in df.columns else "unknown"

# 2) Safe Graphistry auth via env vars
required = ["GRAPHISTRY_USERNAME", "GRAPHISTRY_PASSWORD"]
missing = [k for k in required if not os.getenv(k)]
if missing:
    raise EnvironmentError(f"Missing env vars: {missing}")

register_kwargs = {
    "api": 3,
    "username": os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_USERNAME"],
    "password": os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PASSWORD"],
}
if os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_SERVER"):
    register_kwargs["server"] = os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_SERVER"]
if os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_PROTOCOL"):
    register_kwargs["protocol"] = os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PROTOCOL"]
graphistry.register(**register_kwargs)

# 3) Shape edges + nodes, add degree-like enrichment
edges = df[["src", "dst", "event_time", "event_type", "outcome"]].drop_duplicates()
nodes = pd.DataFrame({"id": pd.unique(pd.concat([edges["src"], edges["dst"]], ignore_index=True))})
deg = pd.concat([edges["src"], edges["dst"]], ignore_index=True).value_counts().rename_axis("id").reset_index(name="degree")
nodes = nodes.merge(deg, on="id", how="left").fillna({"degree": 0})
nodes["degree"] = nodes["degree"].astype(int)
nodes["type"] = nodes["id"].str.split(":", n=1).str[0].where(nodes["id"].str.contains(":"), "entity")
nodes["label"] = nodes["id"].str.split(":", n=1).str[-1]
nodes["risk"] = pd.cut(nodes["degree"], bins=[-1, 1, 3, 10**9], labels=["low", "medium", "high"]).astype(str)

g = graphistry.edges(edges, "src", "dst").nodes(nodes, "id")

# 4) Focused GFQL extraction: denied flows from users to IPs
g_focus = g.gfql([
    n({"type": "user"}),
    e_forward(edge_query="outcome == 'deny'", min_hops=1, max_hops=2),
    n({"type": "ip"})
])

# 5) Visual styling + private sharing + non-inline URL
styled = (
    g_focus.bind(point_label="label", point_color="risk", edge_color="event_type")
    .encode_point_size("degree")
    .encode_point_color("risk", categorical_mapping={"low": "#9CA3AF", "medium": "#F59E0B", "high": "#DC2626"})
    .encode_point_icon("type", categorical_mapping={"user": "user", "ip": "network-wired", "host": "desktop", "entity": "circle"})
```

case_prompt: Write one concise Python workflow (single code block) from raw CSV interactions to a share-safe graph investigation: ingest data, normalize time, do safe Graphistry auth (env vars), shape edges+nodes, add one degree-like enrichment, run one focused GFQL extraction, apply visual styling, set private privacy mode, and return a non-inline URL.
response_text:
```python
import os
import pandas as pd
import graphistry
from graphistry import n, e_forward

# Expected CSV columns: src,dst,timestamp,event_type,amount
edges = pd.read_csv("interactions.csv")
edges["src"] = edges["src"].astype(str).str.strip()
edges["dst"] = edges["dst"].astype(str).str.strip()
edges["ts"] = pd.to_datetime(edges["timestamp"], utc=True, errors="coerce")
edges["event_type"] = edges["event_type"] if "event_type" in edges.columns else "interaction"
edges["amount"] = pd.to_numeric(edges["amount"], errors="coerce").fillna(0.0) if "amount" in edges.columns else 0.0
edges = edges.dropna(subset=["src", "dst", "ts"]).drop_duplicates(subset=["src", "dst", "ts", "event_type"])

# Node table + degree-like enrichment
nodes = pd.DataFrame({"id": pd.unique(pd.concat([edges["src"], edges["dst"]], ignore_index=True))})
degree = (
    edges["src"].value_counts().add(edges["dst"].value_counts(), fill_value=0)
    .astype(int).rename_axis("id").reset_index(name="degree")
)
nodes = nodes.merge(degree, on="id", how="left").fillna({"degree": 0})
nodes["degree"] = nodes["degree"].astype(int)
nodes["degree_bucket"] = pd.cut(
    nodes["degree"], bins=[-1, 1, 3, 10, 10**9], labels=["0-1", "2-3", "4-10", "11+"]
).astype(str)

# Safe auth via environment variables
if os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_ID") and os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_SECRET"):
    graphistry.register(
        api=3,
        server=os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_SERVER", "https://hub.graphistry.com"),
        personal_key_id=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_ID"],
        personal_key_secret=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_SECRET"],
    )
else:
    graphistry.register(
        api=3,
        server=os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_SERVER", "https://hub.graphistry.com"),
        username=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_USERNAME"],
        password=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PASSWORD"],
        org_name=os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_ORG_NAME"),
        idp_name=os.getenv("GRAPHISTRY_IDP_NAME"),
    )

g = graphistry.edges(edges, "src", "dst").nodes(nodes, "id")

# Focused GFQL extraction: high-value transfers
g_focus = g.gfql([n(), e_forward(edge_query="amount >= 10000"), n()])

# Visual styling + share-safe privacy + non-inline URL
g_viz = (
    g_focus.bind(
        point_label="id",
        point_color="degree_bucket",
        point_size="degree",
        edge_color="event_type"
    )
    .encode_point_color(
        "degree_bucket",
        categorical_mapping={"0-1": "#93c5fd", "2-3": "#60a5fa", "4-10": "#2563eb", "11+": "#1e3a8a"},
        default_mapping="#94a3b8",
    )
    .settings(url_params={"info": True, "play": 0})
)

graphistry.privacy(mode="private")
plot_url = g_viz.plot(render=False)
print(plot_url)
```

```python
import os
import pandas as pd
import graphistry
from graphistry import n, e_forward

# events: row-oriented table with at least:
# event_id, ts, user, ip, device, process, action
events = events.copy()
events["ts"] = pd.to_datetime(events["ts"], utc=True, errors="coerce")
events["ts_hour"] = events["ts"].dt.floor("h").astype(str)     # temporal enrichment
events["ts_day"] = events["ts"].dt.date.astype(str)

graphistry.register(
    api=3,
    personal_key_id=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_ID"],
    personal_key_secret=os.environ["GRAPHISTRY_PERSONAL_KEY_SECRET"],
)

# 1) Hypergraph shaping from wide event rows
hg = graphistry.hypergraph(
    events,
    ["user", "ip", "device", "process", "action", "ts_hour", "ts_day"]
)
g = hg["graph"]  # pre-bound graph object from hypergraph result

# 2) Focused traversal (seed -> 1..2 hops)
seed_user = "alice"
g_focus = g.gfql([
    n({"type": "user", "nodeTitle": seed_user}),
    e_forward(min_hops=1, max_hops=2),
    n()
])

# 3) Static-ish layout/view settings + plotting
graphistry.privacy(mode="private")
(
    g_focus
    .bind(point_label="nodeTitle", point_color="type", edge_color="type")
    .settings(url_params={"play": 0, "info": True})  # play=0 keeps view non-animated
    .plot()
)
```

If your hypergraph node label column is not `nodeTitle`, swap `point_label` and the seed predicate to your actual node-id/title column.
